page.lettertext:
fol.13r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have imparted as yow willed
her
Hig
es
pleasure to
e
States
for
e calling away of
S
r
Francis Vere
, to be conferred w
t
a while in some attempts of
great importance against
e co
m
on Enemie. And to
e end
at his departure might not seeme over
strange, nor falle prejudiciall to
e actions of
e
Contrey, I lette them knowe
at her Hig
es
was desy-
rous to proceede w
t
their privitie and good liking.
Wherto they made no other scruple in their answear
unto me, but
at they would consult w
t
e
Coun-
sell of Estate
and likewise w
t
Co. Maurice
, who
had all
e Conduction of
e affaires of
e warres,
and doe me thereupon to witte their answear to her
Ma
tie
, wherin it may be they will signifie, howe
muche it
may
doth
prejudice
e state of their affaires
to have any chief co
m
ander revoked on
e soddaine
(for so they doe debate it in their private co
m
unications)
and will therupon request to have him p
nt
ly retur-
ned. But I thinke they will not use anie other oppo-
sition: and though they should, I knowe it will not
prevaile w
t
S
r
France Vere. My
L: of Essex
dis-
patch w
t
her Ma
ties
l
re
, I sent p
nt
ly for
Duisbourgh
by a Post of this Contrey,
at was trustie and speedie,
at I recken for his coming within two or three dayes
and
at longer then he taketh leave of
e States,
he will not not stay in this place. Two dayes past (to
goe forward where I ended my last to yo
r
L. which I
hope yow have receaved)
M
r
Barnevelt
[returned]
having bin, as I signified imployed into
Zeland,
And
to tell a long tale, as short as I can, he and other five
of
e Province of
Holland,
w
t
fower out of Zeland,
were all
at were deputed to meete in
at Session,
And though they came for other buisnesse, yet
at
being ended, they were contented all at last, being
dealt w
th
all before, and privatly prepared by M
r
Barnevelts diligence, to deliberat there together about
e mater of
e Ouverture: which they discussed at
e
least for tenne or twelve meetinges. Many dangers and
doubtes were alleaged among them, aswell in regard of
inconvenience to
e contrey, which as dyvers discoursed
fol.13v
by a voluntarie dissolution of their Tre[atie with her Majestie]
might be mightilie damnified, as of [peril to them-]
selves, and their owne proper welfar[e when as]
they should be noted, to be movers a[nd advancers]
of suche kinde of Projectes. The eff[ect of their]
objections, I have formerly declared by s[undrie l
res
]
to yo
r
L. They urged mo
st
of all, th[e compositions]
of their State, of suche diversitie of fa[ctions, humours,]
religions: where so many were desyrous [if good]
mater were offered, to sette all a fyre: the [weightie]
bourden of their imposts, and other kinde of [[tallages]]
the peoples wearinesse in g
na
ll to continue [still in]
warre: the faire conditions of Accord presented [by the]
Enemie, w
ch
their neighbors
e Germanes, a[s the Ene-]
mies pledges would undertake to see perfourm[ed and]
a number of other baites and fraudulent de[vises]
which would be practised, they thought, by som[e that were]
corrupted, or ill disposed, of themselves, To [which when]
this shall be added of her Ma
ties
intenti
o
, to en[d her]
Contract w
t
e Land, wherby they shalbe force[d to sur-]
charge
e Co
m
on people to raise an other regimen[t, some]
were wonderfull afraid it would turne upside [down]
all, and cause a great confusion. Against [those in]
e ende other Arguments prevailed, to which, t[hrough]
orderly persuasion they thought
e people would [give]
eare: Her Hig
es
huge expences, for ten yeres [together,]
her p
nt
urgent neede in her domesticall affaire[s her]
earnest poursuite, so long continued
for some
convenie[nt rem-]
boursem
t
: her impression deepely fixed of thei[r un-]
thankefull disposition: her assistance reduced[d to very]
fewe Companies, and those not unlykelie to be [cassed]
and revoked: her undoubted inclination no[to to leave]
them unassisted, if so be
at heereafter they be [driven to]
extremitie: and lastly but in special, her sus[pected]
resolution (for
ei doubt it highly) to watche [a time of]
revenge, when they shall happelie be forced [to a]
large restitution. Upon this they concluded [by a plura-]
litie of voices. For
e first point
at it wa[s expedient]
for them to intertaine 4000 souldiors of
e [English]
nation, not onely in respect of their valor ab[ove others,]
fol.14r
but to countenance their warres, aswell in
e opinion of
their owne inhabitants, as also of other Contreys,
and of
e Enemie chiefly, as if her Ma
tie
would pro-
tect and support their cause unto
e last.
For
e second point,
at it should be referred to her
Hig
es
choise, to discharge or continew her Auxiliarie
forces. For
e third,
at at
e day of her Hig
es
birth or Coronation, or w
at
other tyme she shall be
pleased, they will p
nt
a certaine payment not yet
agreed upon among them, but as it seemed no
lesse then 20000
li
sterling
every yeare
Fourthly
at they will
not enter into Treatie w
t
e
Kinge of Spaine
, as they
will also requyre
at her Ma
tie
would not w
th
out mu-
tuall consent. Fivethly,
at they will alwayes be
readie, as they are this p
nt
, to send unto her Ma
tie
such nomber of Shippes, w
t
convenient provisi
o
, as their
abilitie will permitte, and her occasions shall re-
quyre. Lastly
at heereafter, when they shalbe
unyted w
t
e rest of
e
Prov
i
ces,
or be otherwise established
in peace and tranquillitie,
ei will p
nt
unto her Hig
es
a farre greater portion then
e former wherof, as before,
there was neither any su
m
e in special, nor yeres accor-
ded of continuance: but they left it as a mater,
at would
easilie be resolved. This co
m
unication was kept very
closse among themselves, w
ch
was had in
e towne of
Zuricksea
,
e place of their assembly. From thens it
was concluded,
at they should p
nt
ly returne to their
several Colleges, and should cary this conference w
t
very great secrecie, every man endevoring underhand
and by degrees to procure
e liking of
e best and
e meetest
persons of their Collegues, by imparting privatly to
them
e whole plotte, or a part onely, and more or lesse,
as
e parties gave occasion. And
at publikely they should
forbeare to propose abruptely, any articles to
e effect afore
mentioned. Onely this in open place was accounted
sufficient,
at assoone as they returned, they should
deliver out of hand, the teno
r
of my last proposition,
and of
e rest of my speeches to
e g
na
ll States, and therupon
fol.14v
demonstrat how behoofull they had foun[d it, in their foresaid]
consultation to consider of some good [course, how to]
gratefie her Ma
tie
: for w
ch
it would be v[ery requisit,]
at soem should be deputed w
t
competent autoritie [to]
move
e generall College at
e Hage, to [resume that]
mater so solemnly, and to advise upon some o[ffer, that might]
both be agreeable to her merites and dig[nity, and not]
unpleasing heere at home, to their Townes and to the multitude.
With this determination they d[eparted to]
their principals, w
t
mutual protestation, at [they would]
use, suche diligence dexteritie and care [to prosecute]
e Ouverture, as unles
e Contrey would oppos[e too eagerly]
ly against it, w
ch
they did not suspect, they [would]
appeere w
t
full comissi
o
in
e g
na
ll college [within]
20 dayes after: and then labor to persuade [the rest of]
of
e Deputies: and by them
e lesser Provinces [which]
doe co
m
only concurre without any Contradic[tion with]
Holland and Zeland, as
e Principal contribu[tors in all]
money maters. I will not weery yo
r
L. w
t
a [tedious]
recitall of other pettie plottes betweene me [and M
r
]
Barnevelt, by w
ch
I am to negotiat w
t
some [persons]
in privat, in an other kinde of forme, for
e [better di-]
gesting and ripning of
e mater, w
ch
I finde [more]
and more full of weightie considerations: a[nd were]
e motifes unto me of my last unfortunat return[e, for that]
I was desyrous where
e Project was so [hard and so]
quaisie and so intricat heere, and so newe [in like]
sort to her Ma
ties
eares, to gaine and compas[se that, in]
a very short space, by
e meanes of my presen[ce, which]
could not I was sure, be maneged by l
re
s or [or by messen-]
gers, for many special causes, but very [lamely and]
defectuously, and w
t
a dangerous losse of a g[reat deal]
of tyme, and of
e present opportunities.
Wheras yo
r
L. would knowe, w
at
opinion is [held of]
Count Hohenloes
affection to
e causes of this [Contrey, I]
doe not finde in conversation,
at
e better sor[t here do]
judge him, to be Spanish or ill affected to
[e State,]
but rather on
e other syde, so sure and so s[ound in]
fol.15r
his love to
e Contrey, as they make no question of it.
True it is
at two monethes agoe, there was great secret no-
tice given by l
re
s out of
Germanie,
from some pers
o
s
of qualitie,
at in lykelyhood had
e meanes to
understand it directly,
at he had uttered some
speeches in favor of a Peace among
e Princes of
Germanie: and
at besydes he had determined, to
salute
e
Prince of Orenge
in his passage towardes
Brussels.
Againe it is observed
at there is very
muche inwardnesse between
e
D. of Brunswicke
and
him: who is undoubtedly supposed to be Minister of
Spaine.
For
e Duke hath of late resigned unto
him dyvers Lordships heere in Holland, as
e Baronie
of
Liesvelt
, and
e Seigneurie of Woorden, w
t
divers
other quillets, w
ch
can not yeeld him so litle, as a
thousand markes by
e yere. But whether it be so
at
all that proceedeth of benevolence in
e Duke or
at
e
Count hath disboursed some money, or otherwise forgone
of his owne in exchange, I can not come to learne.
Once these are suche occasions, for w
ch
of late he hath
incurred
e suspition of wavering, and of a hollowe hart
unto
e state in
e judgement of some fewe. But his con-
tinual profession of one Religion, w
ch
was never yet
stayned w
t
any report, together w
t
his longe and loyal
services heere: his mariage of late w
t
e
Countesse of
Buren
, who is zelous in Religion, and exceedinglie ad-
dicted to all
e causes of this Contrey: and then
e inte-
rest
at he hath in
e
her
States and possessions, w
t
his late
newe investure in
e Duke Brunswickes landes, w
ch
lie heere in Holland, are counted special arguments
of his trust and affection. Howbeyt it is certaine
at Count Maurice and he are become incompatible,
howsoever in their meetinges they passe it w
t
a shewe
of a shallowe civill courtesie. For which many doe
wishe
at Count Maurice or his cariages towardes him,
to would use him better, or altogether worse, and determine
w
t
himself to be fully reconciled (wherof there is no
hope) or devise some quiet meanes, to cause him to
fol.15v
depart. For every man doth feare
[at this lingering]
hart burning, w
t
mixture of disgra[ces will drive]
him in
e end to some desperat course [of dealing,]
w
ch
by reason of his alliance and acq[uaintance]
w
t
e Germaines, is nothing needefull [for this Contrey.]
The States I doe finde, could be will[ing enough]
to give him his passeport, but
ei owe h[im at the least]
for arrierages of his services, three score th[ousand]
poundes sterling: for recovering wherof [he will]
be able w
t
his frindes to vexe and molest [every Pro-]
vince
of
in
this contrey. It is not doubted v[ery much,]
but
at he meant to goe see, and visit
e P[. of Orange]
of his voyage had bin neere him, for
e singu[lar love]
at he bare to his father (wherof he make[th often]
mention) and for his matching w
t
his sis[ter: which]
may move him perhaps to treat w
t
e Princ[e, to]
forgoe his Seigneuries in these Provinces, o[f which the]
Prince is proprietarie, by
e right of his mo[ther the]
Countesse of Buren
, though his sister reape
e [revenue]
There hath nothing yet passed, by writ[ing or]
by message, nor heere is nothing geven out o[ut of any]
humor in
e prince, as favoring or hating
[e people]
of this union: But one
at hath bin ever as [his]
Gouvernor w
t
him, doth nowe, as heeretofore [at his]
being in Spaine both send and write to
e C[ountesse]
of Hohenlo, about
e recyeving of his rentes, w[herof the]
Countesse hath alwayes, and doth allowe him [a cer-]
taine portion. Of
e nombers remaini[ng of the]
English bandes,
at are heere in
e service and [pay of]
e States; because they were not mustered sin[ce the mo-]
neth of No
v
: I can come to no certaintie, but [what they]
were then yo
r
L. shall see by
e list heerein[closed with]
e places of their garrisons. In other affa[irs of]
these Provinces, and in
e actions of
e Enemi[e there is]
nothing heere in talke, but is either uncer[taine of]
of
at nature, as yo
r
L. will not care to unders[tand it.]
The Cardinal cometh slowely, remaining [yet in]
Lorrayne,
or as some men say at
Luxembourg
[with 6000]
fol.16r
foote, and 1200 horse, and till his coming, we doe
imagine there wilbe nothing by them attempted
against us, and for us, we are not readie to doe any
thinge of moment.
And thus I take my humble
leave From
e Hague Ja
n
25
95
.
Heere are some of opinion, upon l
re
s out of
Gelderland
at
S
r
Francis Vere is either gone, or going about some peece
of service: w
ch
I am very certaine, if
e Post came to
him, before his departure, he will give over: if not,
for
at I ghesse, it is onely some exploit of surprise, or
to beat some convoy of
e Enemie, it wilbe quickly
perfourmed.
